intro: Clinopodium woronowii, commonly known as Russian lavender or Siberian mint, is a perennial herb native to the cold climates of Eastern Europe and Siberia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a fragrant, minty aroma. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in whorls along the stems. Clinopodium woronowii is often used in traditional medicine for its purported calming and antiseptic properties.
